Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Characterization of Glutamate Receptors in the Pond Snails, Helisoma Trivolvis and Biomphalaria Glabrata
Award.AbstractNarration: Glutamate is a neurotransmitter (a chemical that elicits signals in neurons) that is important for everyday function in both vertebrate and invertebrate animals. In pond snails it controls the pattern of feeding behavior, in which the animals use a tongue-like organ to scrape food from a substrate. The central questions in this project are about how glutamate activates and inhibits certain neurons to cause the muscular movements that define normal feeding behavior. To determine which neurons glutamate affects, the receptor proteins that glutamate binds to will be tagged with markers (antibodies) that can be visualized with fluorescence microscopy. The excitation and inhibition induced by glutamate in these labeled neurons will then be examined, and the relationship of this activity to known patterns activity that drive feeding will be assessed. It is expected that neurons that are labeled with glutamate receptor antibodies will respond to glutamate, and have a role in the control of feeding in these organisms. Understanding the receptors that bind glutamate in this system has two important consequences: 1) these receptors can be compared to those found in vertebrate animals to determine how glutamate receptors have changed (or not) during evolution; 2) the mechanism by which a limited number of neurons and neurotransmitters control a behavior like feeding can be better understood. The work is providing important training opportunities for three undergraduates who will conduct research during the summers, and several other students who will conduct thesis research on these projects during the academic year.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Simple rhythmic behaviors like chewing, breathing and walking are under the control of small networks of neurons that, when active, are sufficient to cause the behavior by activating motor neurons that stimulate muscle activity. Even simple behaviors, though, must be subject to modulation in order to respond to internal and external environments. The experiments supported by this grant were designed to better understand the modulation of rhythmic feeding in two species of pond snails. Specifically, the roles of the neurotransmitter glutamate in two-way communication with the neurons that pattern feeding were investigated. Simultaneous recordings were made from the neurons that control feeding and additional neurons that modulate feeding patterns in the presence of chemicals which simulate the activity of glutamate and other modulators. Endogenous chemicals called neuropeptides, in addition to glutamate mimics, stimulated neurons which, in turn, inhibited the swallowing phase of feeding. These chemical switches therefore converted a neural pattern indicative of feeding behavior into one that most likely underlies regurgitation or reproductive behaviors in which the animals clean the substrate for laying eggs. The outcome from this research is a testable model in which a certain groups of neurons are responsive to certain chemicals and mediate switches to a varitey of different oral behaviors. This kind of model is applicable to the groups of neurons that control rhythmic behaviors in all animals, including humans.

A second outcome of this research is the training of 13 undergraduate students in the process of doing research. Students at Bates College work with faculty during the summer and academic semesters. They learn to read the relevant literature and design hypotheses that they subsequently test in the laboratory. Once they have carried out the experiments, they analyze the results, present them to the campus community and write a thesis that describes the research. The students trained under this grant participated in all aspects of the research described above. Most of them have attended regional and/or national conferences to present their research and will be authors on scientific publications. This prepares them well for subsequent graduate and/or professional study after they graduate.
